questions.question: Choose the correct sentence:
options: She go to school every day.
She goes to school every day.
She going to school every day.
She is go to school every day.
questions.explanation: In present simple tense, third person singular (she/he/it) takes 's/es' with the verb: 'goes'.

questions.question: Identify the correct past tense sentence:
options: I go to the market yesterday.
I went to the market yesterday.
I was go to the market yesterday.
I had go to the market yesterday.
questions.explanation: 'Went' is the simple past form of 'go', used with time expressions like 'yesterday'.

questions.question: Choose the correct present continuous sentence:
options: He is play football now.
He playing football now.
He is playing football now.
He are playing football now.
questions.explanation: Present continuous uses 'am/is/are + verb-ing': 'He is playing football now.'

questions.question: Select the correct future 'will' sentence:
options: I will going to the party tomorrow.
I will go to the party tomorrow.
I will went to the party tomorrow.
I will gone to the party tomorrow.
questions.explanation: With 'will', use the base form of the verb: 'will go'.

questions.question: Choose the correct present perfect sentence:
options: She has finished her homework.
She have finished her homework.
She has finish her homework.
She had finished her homework now.
questions.explanation: Present perfect uses 'has/have + past participle'; 'has finished' is correct for 'she'.

questions.question: Identify the correct past continuous sentence:
options: They was playing when I arrived.
They were playing when I arrived.
They are playing when I arrived.
They played when I was arrive.
questions.explanation: Past continuous uses 'was/were + verb-ing'; with 'they' use 'were playing'.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence for a habit:
options: He is smoking every day.
He smokes every day.
He smoked every day now.
He has smoked every day now.
questions.explanation: Habits in the present are expressed with present simple: 'He smokes every day.'

questions.question: Select the correct past perfect sentence:
options: When I arrived, he left.
When I arrived, he has left.
When I arrived, he had left.
When I arrived, he was left.
questions.explanation: Past perfect ('had left') shows an action finished before another past action ('arrived').

questions.question: Choose the correct future 'going to' sentence:
options: We are going to visit them next week.
We going to visit them next week.
We will going to visit them next week.
We are visit them next week.
questions.explanation: The 'going to' future uses 'am/is/are going to + base verb': 'are going to visit'.

questions.question: Identify the correct present simple question:
options: Do she like coffee?
Does she likes coffee?
Does she like coffee?
Do she likes coffee?
questions.explanation: With 'does', the main verb stays in base form: 'Does she like coffee?'.

questions.question: Choose the correct present continuous question:
options: Is you coming with us?
Are you coming with us?
Do you coming with us?
You are coming with us?
questions.explanation: Present continuous questions use 'am/is/are' before the subject: 'Are you coming... ?'.

questions.question: Select the correct use of present perfect for life experience:
options: I have seen that movie last week.
I saw that movie already.
I have already seen that movie.
I already see that movie.
questions.explanation: Present perfect with 'already' uses 'have/has + past participle': 'have already seen'.

questions.question: Choose the correct past simple negative sentence:
options: She didn't went to work yesterday.
She not went to work yesterday.
She didn't go to work yesterday.
She doesn't went to work yesterday.
questions.explanation: With 'didn't', the main verb remains in base form: 'didn't go'.

questions.question: Identify the correct future simple question:
options: Will you come tomorrow?
Do you will come tomorrow?
Are you will come tomorrow?
You will come tomorrow?
questions.explanation: Future simple questions use 'Will + subject + base verb': 'Will you come tomorrow?'.

questions.question: Choose the correct present perfect continuous sentence:
options: He has been work here since 2019.
He has been working here since 2019.
He is working here since 2019.
He was working here since 2019.
questions.explanation: Present perfect continuous uses 'has/have been + verb-ing' for actions from past until now.

questions.question: Select the correct past continuous with interruption:
options: I cooked dinner when the phone rang.
I was cooked dinner when the phone rang.
I was cooking dinner when the phone rang.
I cooking dinner when the phone rang.
questions.explanation: An action in progress interrupted by another uses past continuous + past simple: 'was cooking' + 'rang'.

questions.question: Choose the correct mixed tenses sentence:
options: I am usually getting up at 6 a.m.
I usually get up at 6 a.m.
I usually am getting up at 6 a.m.
I was usually get up at 6 a.m.
questions.explanation: Habits use present simple, not present continuous: 'I usually get up at 6 a.m.'.

questions.question: Identify the correct sentence for a fixed future timetable:
options: The train will leave at 7 p.m.
The train leaves at 7 p.m.
The train is leaving at 7 p.m. yesterday.
The train left at 7 p.m. tomorrow.
questions.explanation: Fixed schedules can be expressed with present simple: 'The train leaves at 7 p.m.'.

questions.question: Choose the correct tense for an action completed just now:
options: I just finished my homework.
I have just finish my homework.
I have just finished my homework.
I just have finished my homework yesterday.
questions.explanation: Recent completion often uses present perfect: 'have just finished'.

questions.question: Select the correct sentence showing a longâ€‘term habit in the past:
options: We were used to play here as kids.
We used to playing here as kids.
We used to play here as kids.
We are used to play here as kids.
questions.explanation: 'Used to + base verb' expresses a past habit: 'used to play'.

questions.question: Choose the correct tense for a decision made at the moment of speaking:
options: I am going to open the window.
I will open the window.
I opened the window.
I have opened the window.
questions.explanation: Spontaneous decisions are usually expressed with 'will + base verb'.

questions.question: Identify the correct sentence for a planned future action:
options: I think I will visit my parents next weekend.
I am going to visit my parents next weekend.
I visit my parents next weekend.
I visited my parents next weekend.
questions.explanation: 'Be going to' is used for plans or intentions: 'am going to visit'.

questions.question: Choose the correct past perfect continuous sentence:
options: She had been waiting for an hour when the bus arrived.
She has been waiting for an hour when the bus arrived.
She was waiting for an hour when the bus had arrived.
She had waited for an hour when the bus was arriving.
questions.explanation: Past perfect continuous ('had been waiting') shows a long action before another past event.

questions.question: Select the correct sentence contrasting present simple and present continuous:
options: Right now, I read a book, but usually I am watching TV.
Right now, I am reading a book, but usually I watch TV.
Right now, I read a book, but usually I watch TV.
Right now, I am reading a book, but usually I am watch TV.
questions.explanation: Use present continuous for 'right now' and present simple for habits: 'am reading' / 'usually I watch'.

questions.question: Choose the correct tense to describe something true for a long time and still true:
options: He lives in Mumbai for ten years.
He is living in Mumbai for ten years.
He has lived in Mumbai for ten years.
He lived in Mumbai for ten years and still lives there.
questions.explanation: Present perfect ('has lived') is used for actions that started in the past and continue to now.

questions.question: Identify the correct future continuous sentence:
options: This time tomorrow, I will work.
This time tomorrow, I will be working.
This time tomorrow, I am working.
This time tomorrow, I will working.
questions.explanation: Future continuous uses 'will be + verb-ing' to show an action in progress at a future time.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence to express a scheduled future using present continuous:
options: I am meeting the manager at 5 p.m. tomorrow.
I meet the manager at 5 p.m. tomorrow.
I will meeting the manager at 5 p.m. tomorrow.
I am going the manager at 5 p.m. tomorrow.
questions.explanation: Present continuous can express personal fixed future arrangements: 'I am meeting...'.

questions.question: Select the correct sentence showing a general truth:
options: Water is boiling at 100 degrees Celsius.
Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius.
Water is boils at 100 degrees Celsius.
Water boiled at 100 degrees Celsius always.
questions.explanation: General truths and facts are expressed in present simple: 'Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius.'

questions.question: Choose the correct tense for an action that finished before now with no time given:
options: I finished my homework.
I have finished my homework.
I was finished my homework.
I had finished my homework now.
questions.explanation: Without a specific past time, present perfect ('have finished') is preferred to show completion before now.

questions.question: Identify the correct mixed tenses sentence:
options: I didn't see him since Monday.
I haven't seen him since Monday.
I don't see him since Monday.
I am not seeing him since Monday.
questions.explanation: With 'since' and a point in time until now, present perfect is used: 'haven't seen'.
